description: From Middle English stepel, from Old English stīpel, stȳpel, stīepel (“tower, steeple”), from Proto-Germanic *staupilaz (“that which is steep, tower, steeple”), equivalent to steep +‎ -le. Cognate with Old Norse stǫpull (“tower, steeple”).

entries.meaning: A tall tower, often on a church, normally topped with a spire.
(historical) A high headdress of the 14th century.

verbs.description: steeple (third-person singular simple present steeples, present participle steepling, simple past and past participle steepled)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To form something into the shape of a steeple.
examples: He steepled his fingers as he considered the question.
